rows.block1_text::eng:
**Routines – Fraction Areas – Rectangle Fractions**

The challenge is to identify the fraction of the whole design that each color has (considering all pieces of one color together).

You have several choices for how to present these to your students using dividing lines. You can present them with minimal lines, no lines, or with extra lines. Using extra lines provides practice with identifying equivalent fractions. For example, in the first diagram (using all modes), the blue section can be seen as 3/8, 6/16, or 12/32.
rows.block2_text::eng: These diagrams are presented in pairs, but each diagram is a separate puzzle.

rows.block1_text::eng:
**Routines – Fraction Areas – Unusual Baker**

The story for these diagrams is that there is an unusual baker that likes to cut his cakes into odd shaped pieces. He likes to charge $10 for the whole cake, and he wants to know how much he should charge for each piece. The two cutting patterns in each pair are independent puzzles.

Of course, you can also ask what the fraction of the whole thing each piece is. Also, you can assign a size, say 1, to one of the pieces and then come up with values for all the other pieces.
